noun.description: A disorderly retreat of defeated troops.
examples: the retreat degenerated into a rout
the army was in a state of demoralization verging on rout

noun.description: An assembly of people who have made a move toward committing an illegal act which would constitute an offense of riot.
A large evening party or reception.

verb.description: Defeat and cause to retreat in disorder.
examples: in a matter of minutes the attackers were routed

phrases: I once put a gang to rout
This argument is soon put to rout by the assumption that if the remaining days of a centenarian are a mere repetition of yesterday, what delight can be derived from such a pitiable living?
The ills of bias and discrimination have been put to rout.
I wanted to live deep and suck out all the marrow of life, to live so sturdily and Spartan-like as to put to rout all that was not life.
A quick trip across the blogosphere immediately puts to rout the notion that Cosby's thoughts were either new or simply one half of a liberal/conservative schism.
origin: Mid 16th century (in rout (sense 2)): alteration of the verb root. rout (sense 1) dates from the early 19th century.
